action.action-desc: Mr. Torres of New York introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to require issuers to disclose whether they do business in, or with Russia or other aggressor nations, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Reveal Risky Business in Russia Act.

section.header: Disclosure of business ties to Russia or other aggressor nations
section.text: Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (15 U.S.C. 78m) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.header: Disclosure of business ties to Russia or other aggressor nations

paragraph.text: Each issuer required to file an annual or quarterly report under subsection (a) shall disclose in that report whether the issuer does business in or with—

subparagraph.text: any country that, after March 24, 2022, invades a sovereign nation state or annexes sovereign territory in an unprovoked war of aggression.

paragraph.text: The requirements under paragraph (1) shall cease to have any force or effect on the earlier of—

subparagraph.text: the date that is 5 years after the date of enactment of this subsection; and
the date on which the Commission—

clause.text: determines that such requirements are not in the public interest or for the protection of investors; and
notifies the Congress of such determination, and makes such determination available to the public.
